title: Installing Java 25 (OpenJDK) on Linux
context: I wanted to install Java 25 (OpenJDK 25) on my Linux system and configure it for development, ensuring the java and javac commands work globally.
keyIdea: Use the system package manager or official tarball from Adoptium/OpenJDK to install Java 25, then configure JAVA_HOME and PATH to make it globally available.
commands:
# Debian / Ubuntu
sudo apt update
sudo apt install openjdk-25-jdk

# Fedora / RHEL
sudo dnf install java-25-openjdk-devel

# Arch Linux
sudo pacman -S jdk-openjdk

# Verify installation
java -version
javac -version

# Set environment variables (permanent)
echo 'export JAVA_HOME=$(dirname $(dirname $(readlink -f $(which java))))' | sudo tee -a /etc/profile.d/java.sh
echo 'export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH' | sudo tee -a /etc/profile.d/java.sh
sudo chmod +x /etc/profile.d/java.sh
source /etc/profile.d/java.sh

# Check configuration
echo $JAVA_HOME
java -version
explanation: Installing OpenJDK 25 ensures access to the latest Java runtime and compiler. Package managers simplify maintenance and updates. The JAVA_HOME variable points to the JDK root, allowing build tools (like Maven or Gradle) to detect Java automatically. Updating PATH ensures global access to the java binaries.

reusabilityNotes.whenToReuse: Whenever you need to install or upgrade to a new Java version or configure system-wide Java environment.
reusabilityNotes.pitfalls: Ensure the package name matches your distributionâ€™s repository. When multiple JDKs exist, use `update-alternatives --config java` (Debian/Ubuntu) to select the active version.
